documents.commentText:
The Food and Drug Administration has statutory authority over all substances sold in interstate commerce within the United States, as a human food, a human nutritional supplement, or as a drug with which to treat a disease.

The Drug Enforcement Agency has statutory authority over substances that have been taken off the market because of their abuse potential or for which the manufacturer or the FDA or the Surgeon General  has concerns for the abuse potential.

Kratom is currently sold as a nutritional supplement in the United States, in interstate commerce.

At present, none of the growers have applied to the FDA for permission to label Kratom as a drug, nor to advertise a kratom-derived drug as being useful for treating or curing any particular disease.

Also at present, there is a pandemic of unrelieved chronic pain in the United States, resulting principally from the large numbers of Iraq War veterans who suffered traumatic brain injury from improvised explosive devices (IED's) used by various combatants in that War.

Numerous veterans are on waiting lists to be seen at VA hospitals and cannot get to them.  Some veterans are overcome by the pain and use firearms to kill themselves.  Others experiment with drugs they can buy from illegal sources. And some have used kratom for pain relief, successfully.

All five Mexican drug trafficking organizations (DTOs) have been killing Iraq War veterans by selling them tablets of controlled substances that contain the high-potency narcotic Fentanyl.  The FDA has approved the sale of Fentanyl by prescription, in a product called the Duragesic Patch, a transdermal drug delivery system worn on the body, that slowly releases the medication into the body.  No US pharmaceutical company has asked FDA for permission to supply Fentanyl in tablet form, because of extreme concern for the likelihood that a patient could die by accidentally biting or cracking open, the tablet, which would cause an excessive amount of Fentanyl to enter the patient's bloodstream.

The narcotic tablets being sold by Mexican DTOs that are killing our veterans, are smuggled into the United States in violation of multiple laws, after manufacture in Mexico from ingredients imported from elsewhere and processed there, in facilities owned and operated by those DTOs, contrary to Mexican and US law.

Kratom is a stimulant.  Like coffee, energy drinks, ADHD medications, and decongestants, an excessive dose can cause extreme discomfort in sensitive individuals.  People with hypertension and those at risk of serotonin syndrome, such as those already taking a stimulant medication or taking an antidepressant drug that alters serotonin metabolism, can experience acute distress from serotonin syndrome when consuming any stimulant.  The physician who prescribes an antidepressant drug, is obligated to check for the occurrence of serotonin syndrome, as it often indicates that the patient no longer needs the antidepressant drug and should be weaned off it or should receive it at a reduced dosage. There have been several media reports of serotonin syndrome in Austin, Texas, to which firefighters responded and the patient spent several hours in the emergency room, receiving an anxiolytic drug and fluids, while recovering from the emergency.  Those reports drew media attention to the fact that ambulances responded, and to the fact that the patients had taken Kratom.  But what was not reported by media, was the fact that the patients got medical assistance that altered the other drugs they were taking, that  led them to reduce their overall consumption of stimulants.

The symptoms of serotonin syndrome are not pleasurable in the least. People who experience it, desire not to induce it again.  Accordingly, the emergencies associated with Kratom, do not affect the entire US population, but only are risks to people who take antidepressants at high doses.  Moreover, there is no likelihood that anyone will repeat the behavior that led to the emergency.  It's simply too unpleasant to experience a racing heartbeat, muscle tremors, nausea, vomiting, dry-heaving, a burning sensation in the throat from dehydration, and an inability to rest or find comfort for several hours.  Nobody feels euphoria by mixing stimulants with antidepressants.  Therefore, there's no reason why a person would develop a habit of it, whether with kratom or with coffee.

DEA should encourage states to pursue research into kratom-based medicines that FDA can approve as drugs, and provide improved warnings for patients who use them with antidepressants.  Given the large numbers of veterans using kratom to ease pain, it's ludicrous to restrict interstate commerce in kratom, by scheduling it as a controlled substance.

documents.commentText:
I am a paramedic with 25 years of emergency medical experience.  

Kratom, while not yet subject to extensive scrutiny by the western medical community, should not be placed on the list of scheduled substances at this time.  The reasons for this are as follows:
1- There is extensive evidence (many thousands of testimonials) that kratom has provided a significant benefit to persons dealing with addiction to opiates.  

2-There is little to no evidence that kratom use has resulted in adverse effects that are disproportionate with its potential utility to society.  While all medications can cause adverse effects, kratom has not shown that those effects are significantly increased such that a harm vs. benefit analysis would indicate there is a potential to create a serious danger to the public.  We recognize that aspirin and acetaminophen, when taken in excess, are extremely dangerous.  However the benefit we derive from widespread easy access to these medications far outweighs the risks.  There are no records in the literature of deaths due to the normal use of kratom; something that few medications can boast of.  What cases there are that involve death or morbidity are a result of complex interactions of numerous legal and illegal substances in a very small population of drug abusers.  Thus, kratom appears to be a relatively safe substance when ingested orally.  While there are several hundred cases of calls to poison control for kratom ingestion, it is worth pointing out that the recent publicity kratom has received due to DEA action has revealed that there are likely hundreds of thousands of kratom users in the US.  This is key to evaluating the risk of kratom: several hundred poison control calls resulting from ~50,000 regular users is of much greater concern than from 500,000 users.  The DEA and CDC must evaluate those calls based on the severity of the incident and in the context of the number of overall users.

3-There may be a potential for addiction to kratom, but this is poorly understood and the currently available evidence, largely anecdotal in nature, indicates that kratom is less addictive than cigarettes.  Most users report that it does not result in severe withdrawal symptoms.  This is likely why kratom has enjoyed considerably success worldwide and throughout history as a treatment for opiate addiction.  Whereas cigarettes confer no benefit and are themselves a carcinogen, a rush to ban kratom due to possible addictive properties may result in greater social harm due to increased illicit drug use.

4- Kratom holds out the possibility of better pain killing medications.  As an EMS provider, all of the currently available opiates and NSAIDs have significant drawbacks which must be carefully weighed for each patient.  However, if kratom is made a scheduled substance, research will be much harder.

5- Many veterans who suffer from PTSD have reported significant improvement of symptoms.   Kratom appears to be an effective alternative to some anti-depressants and sleep medications.  This is another issue that deserves greater scrutiny by the medical community.

Kratom should be regulated.  There are issues of purity and a risk of adulteration from foreign suppliers.  Through the scientific community, studies may indeed show that kratom's risks outweigh its benefits and should be limited to a prescription only substance.  However, we are not there yet, and to arbitrarily ban kratom at this point is likely to cause greater harm than good.

My name is Paula Bishop and I'm 50 years old and am a graphic designer by profession. A friend introduced me to kratom in a tea back in 2011, and I noticed its mildly relaxing effects. Hello,

I'd like to begin by stating that I am a 25 year old male Medical Technologist that suffers from chronic pain, depression, and anxiety. I am opposed to the DEA making the alkaloids in Mitragyna speciosa (kratom) schedule I. 

A few years ago I sought treatment from my physician for chronic abdominal pain that had an unclear etiology. Due to the debilitating nature of this pain, I was initially prescribed Percocet (Oxycodone and Acetaminophen) to be taken a few times a day. My tolerance to this drug increased rapidly and over the course of a year and a half my physician increased my prescription to 40 mg of Oxycontin per day and roughly 40 mg of Percocet per day. I realized that I was becoming dependent on these drugs and became worried about the well-known side effects of the drugs (respiratory depression, narcotic bowel syndrome, etc.) and asked my physician to be weaned off of them completely. Even with a very gradual wean, coming off of oxycodone was incredibly difficult, and the withdrawals were one of the worst experiences of my life. In an attempt to help deal with the symptoms, I set out on the internet to search for an herbal supplement that could help with anxiety, and happened upon Kratom. I came across an enormous number of testimonials of people who used Kratom to help with the opioid withdrawals and were able to successfully stay off of the narcotics thanks to the Kratom. After researching the safety of the plant, and noting that there are no significant side effects and no deaths attributable to the plant (the only recorded deaths where the alkaloids were found in post-mortem toxicology results also involved heavy narcotics such as heroin or oxycodone) I decided to give it a shot. I have now been free of narcotics for well over 3 years with no relapses. I am 100% confident that had it not been for this plant, I would still be taking heavy narcotics for my pain relief. The kratom offers me relief from not only my chronic pain, but it helps me sleep well, reduces my anxiety and depression, and allows me to function much more normally than before. I also would like to note that I have noticed absolutely no dependence on Kratom. I take it when I am feeling significant pain not controlled by Acetaminophen or NSAIDs, and otherwise feel no compulsion to take take it more often than necessary. It provides me no "high;" only a reduction in pain.

I like to compare kratom to valerian root, another herbal supplement that people use for insomnia and anxiety. It is no more dangerous than valerian root which can be bought at just about any drug store or even at department stores. It has been used safely for thousands of years in other parts of the world. There is no reason that kratom needs to be scheduled as a schedule I drug. Before I was an MT, I was a certified pharmacy technician and am very familiar with the scheduling system. Schedule I needs to be reserved for actual drugs of abuse that can cause significant danger to human health. Kratom needs to be classified as an herbal supplement and regulated as such since it has no notable safety concerns and a very small side-effect profile. If it weren't for kratom, I can assure you that the DEA would be dealing with thousands more cases of people seeking out illegal opioid narcotics or abusing the healthcare system for narcotics.

I am confident that should the DEA decide not to schedule Kratom in the same category as heroin and methamphetamine, allowing for studies to be performed, the anecdotal evidence of Kratom's efficacy and safety profile will be made obvious and Kratom will be found on the herbal supplement shelves of drug stores everywhere thanks to its many uses. 

Thank you for allowing the people to speak on this issue and not taking drastic measures. The fact that you have asked for this commentary shows that the DEA can make reasonable decisions and acts based on the desires of the people while considering public safety. Please weigh these out appropriately when making your final decision. The public is not in danger from the very mild effects of Kratom and its alkaloids. The public is very much in danger from the addictive and dangerous effects of both legal and illegal opioids and focus should be placed on the overprescribing of opiates and reducing available illegal opioids while placing emphasis on recovery rather than incarceration for those afflicted with addiction. Thank you again.

documents.commentText:
My name is Joe deAlcuaz. I serve as the Secretary for the Institute of Food Technologists, Longhorn Chapter, and am the Director of Yeast Leavened R&D and SQF Practitioner at Bridgford Food Processing of Texas LP. I am an Eagle Scout, and recently a volunteer for the International Rescue Committee. I am also a responsible kratom user.

In high school, I weighed over 240 lbs and led a relatively sedentary, depressed life. My depression led to my lifestyle which fed my depression cyclically. This changed in college when I began running regularly, dropped to 185 lbs, and garnered the emotional willpower to lead a more outgoing life. That's all well and good for a 19 year old, but I am 29 now. 10 years of running 4-7 miles, 4-5 times a week, while enabling me to live an objectively better life, has fostered chronic muscle pain I feel all day, every day. Some days the pain is so stubborn I can't run more than a mile and a half. When this happens I fall back into the depressive state that plagued my younger years, and it is absolutely terrifying. The thought that I could descend back into that place because I'm physically incapable of maintaining a healthy habit, that it could alter the direction of my career and personal life for the worst, that is unacceptable.

I went to 2 doctors who recommended several things, opioids, muscle relaxers, and even self-medication with Texas's prison-quota-filler a la creme, marijuana. Depressing, yes? That according to doctors, my options consisted of poison that is killing Americans in unprecedented numbers and living outside the boundaries of lawful citizenry. (see:Eagle Scout)

When kratom entered the public eye after the FDA's initial letter, I became curious instantly. Its advocates described an effective painkiller that, juxtaposed with comparable prescription products, is relatively side effect free, a reliable mood stabilizer, and inexpensive. Opponents to its legalization dubbed the drug, "herbal heroin," a blight on our society with no medical use whatsoever, much like opium (morphine) and marijuana (CBD oil). The advocates' arguments were far less logically and morally problematic, so I decided to give it a try.

I took my first dose, 4 grams orally, 3 months ago. Not only was the constant ache of my active lifestyle subdued, but my mood and productivity at work were elevated and remarkably stable. I haven't missed a single running date since, and have started running a 13 miles, a half marathon, every 2 weeks. So the advocates are correct; responsible kratom use has the potential to improve people's lives.

But could kratom alone be dangerous? The "alone" qualifier is important, because you need to apply the same logical and moral standards across the board. E.g., Alcohol and Tylenol are two very legal substances, and should remain so. However combined, they are deadly, sending approximately 60k Americans to the emergency room and killing hundreds every year. As it is not ok to determine the legal status of alcohol based upon its interaction with Tylenol, prohibiting kratom use because people are unwise enough to take it with other substances is silly. I took it upon myself to determine the physical and emotional side effects of kratom "abuse" and withdrawal, understanding that no two people are physiologically the same, ergo mine and all reactions are unique. I increased my dose to 6 grams, 8, then 14 to see if the uncharacteristic increase in dosage would catch my body off guard. I maintained my 14 gram a day regimen for a week, and while I noticed more perspiration and  pronounced feelings of calm and relaxation, according to my coworkers and friends, it did not alter my behavior in any significant way. I ran typically fast, and felt typically satisfied with life.

The end of my experiment was happily uneventful. I quit cold turkey, and expected to experience severe emotional distress and physical pains, like when I quit smoking cigarettes. Neither came. I continued running, more capable because of my 2 months of increased physical activity. Even though I ran slower, I had no trouble finishing 4, 8, or 13 miles without walking. I felt mild ennui at the office, but was able to focus and solve complex problems without the sheer grief and anxiety that accompanied nicotine withdrawal. With respect to my own body, given my experience should be subject to the same side effects detractors cling to when they laud kratom, "herbal heroin," it is my opinion as a scientist that their statements regarding the harmful effects of kratom are categorically false.

A government has the right to restrict access to substances that in normal use infringe upon the rights of its society. Cocaine, a highly addictive and life destroying drug, should clearly be illegal. What is not clear is why anyone would ban a substance with such potential to improve peoples lives without consequence. On the contrary, that the FDA would do so without firmer scientific grounds is extremely troubling.

documents.commentText:
Re: request for public comments, Mitragyna speciosa (kratom)

From: MK Austin, PA, MPH

(from J.Osteo. publication)
Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is a botanical product that has a history of being sold as a dietary supplement and has been used to manage pain and boost energy. Mitragyna speciosa grows naturally in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Papua New Guinea and has been used for many years in Southeast Asia as an opium substitute. In recent years there has been an increase in use of kratom in the United States ...

Clearly, formal studies, both pharmaceutical and clinical, are needed to determine appropriate dosage, use, and action.

Well-designed RTCs would be helpful.

As with all medicinal agents, interaction with other phamaceuticals/agents can be problematic, and may be part of the unfortunate instances with this botanical.

Another factor can be placebo effect, and the intention of the person taking this botanical deserves attention.  While I have spoken with people who claimed to have had psychological experiences, that was not my experience at all.

While anecdotal, the experience of a trained medical observer may offer some information.

My first ingestion of this botanical was as a tea, at a local coffee shop.
I do not know the exact amount the proprietor mixed in the tea, but I did have a completely empty stomach ... and developed transient nausea.

The following week, I had the tea (1/2-1 teaspoon in a cup of juice/mint tea) after a meal, and did not experience nausea.
I used this botanical for moderate musculoskeletal pain, much as one would use OTC NSAIDs, and I found the effect very similar to OTC naproxen sodium.
Using the 1 teaspoon dose in a cup of mint tea/juice, twice a day for 10 days.

I discontinued abruptly, and had no negative sx. Since that time, I have used the 1 teaspoon dose in a cup of mint tea/juice between meals, intermittently, as I would use OTC naproxen sodium.

My experience with NSAIDs is that after a few days of use, my clotting factors seem to be affected, and I did not have this experience with the botanical kratom.


My view, is that it is similar to OTC naproxen sodium in analgesic effect; I did not experience any significant side-effects; I did not use it with any other medications or agents.

Thank you for your serious consideration of this plant's beneficial history in widespread use.

Respectfully submitted,

MK Austin, PA, MPH

The following is a letter I wrote to my local congressman, Steve Stivers, which I would like to share with the public, though I don't want to post my real name on this public forum. Mr. Stivers has done a lot of work to control opiate abuse in Ohio, and I would like to make the case that banning kratom would cause us to lose ground in those efforts.

Hello Mr. Stivers,

I work as a school teacher, and I care deeply about the well-being of our young people. Recently, the DEA announced its intention to move the kratom plant to the list of Schedule I substances. I would like to ask you to help stop this from happening.

I have been reading about your recent efforts to combat the opioid addiction epidemic, and I'm really happy to see that you care about the diverse group of people who fall victim to this terrible affliction. Preventing unused prescription opioids from getting onto the streets is a commonsense plan, and I hope it becomes law. I believe if kratom gets banned, the opioid epidemic will get even worse. Let me explain why.

My mother was dependent on oxycodone to manage her pain from carcinoid cancer, and after she passed away, my little sister abused and become addicted to her hundreds of leftover pills. The kratom plant saved my sister's life. After trying and failing to get off the prescription pills in a variety of ways, she found kratom, and used it to ease herself off of the prescription meds. I've since learned that there are many like her who've used the plant in a similar way.

Kratom is a plant native to East Asia and have been used by the people there as a traditional medicine for over 1000 years. It is a relative to the coffee tree, and has analgesic and some mild opioid-like effects. Taken in small doses, it takes away the urge to use opiates, and for many, acts similar to an anti-depressant, with a mild, mood-lifting effect. Taken in larger doses, it mimics opiates in some ways, but it's much milder, and with fewer side effects. There is also no chance of overdosing (people will vomit if too much is taken).
 
Kratom is a 100% organic leaf that is dried and ground into a powder, but some are adulterating it, or making super-concentrated versions of it and putting it into head shops, marketing it as a drug of abuse, similar to synthetic marijuana. This is a big part of the reason why it is getting attention and a bad reputation among lawmakers.
As kratom is getting more popular, people are discovering that it is very effective in helping overcome opioid addiction. It can ease withdrawal symptoms and also act as a maintenance medication, much safer than something like suboxone or methadone.

I believe if this plant is made illegal, its users will turn back to opiates. As you know, that's a dangerous game, as fentanyl-laced heroin and the like is killing off addicts in Ohio by the dozen. Many opiate addicts don't even know kratom exists, and I think we should be using it help people instead of lumping it in with synthetic drugs that are part of the problem.
Please look into this and help fight the opioid addiction problem by keeping kratom legal! 

Thank you

When has kratom actually been a problem? Well, never, until the DEA decided to make it a problem. Just like Harry Anslinger did before them, DEA bureaucrats are demonizing a substance to justify their own existence. The DEA couldn't care less about whether a given drug is truly a threat to public health or not. According to the DEA, there have been 15 deaths attributed to kratom between 2014 and 2016. Fifteen, in two years. Is that a public health threat? What the DEA fails to point out is that those fifteen deaths stemmed from the use of other drugs in combination with kratom (per three published studies, one in "Journal of Forensic Sciences" and two in "Journal of Analytical Toxicology"). 
Fifteen deaths in two years, allegedly from kratom use. Compare that to the annual number of alcohol-related deaths in the U.S.: 88,000 (https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/alcohol-health/overview-alcohol-consumption/alcohol-facts-and-statistics: "Nearly 88,000 people ... die from alcohol-related causes annually, making alcohol the fourth leading preventable cause of death in the United States...."). That's 241 deaths PER DAY from alcohol use in the United States alone. 
Compare alcohol or kratom deaths to the opioid death rate. The DEA and other government agencies are calling the current wave of opioid deaths an epidemic, at 28,000 annually (as of 2014, https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/). That's about 77 deaths per day from opioids. documents.commentText:
I am a physician in Vermont. While I do not advocate the use of kratom by patients I feel that a ban on kratom will hinder research on a possibly beneficial treatment alternative to opioids for pain.  It is important to study the effects of this plant and to determine appropriate use as well as plant- drug interactions. 

During a study period from  January 2010December 2015 the National Poison Data System 
reported 660 calls associated with kratom use. Medical outcomes associated with kratom exposure were reported as minor (minimal signs or symptoms, which resolved rapidly with no residual disability) for 162 (24.5%) exposures, moderate (non-life threatening, with no residual disability, but requiring some form of treatment) for 275 (41.7%) exposures, and major (life-threatening signs or symptoms, with some residual disability) for 49 (7.4%) exposures. One death was reported in a person who was exposed to the medications paroxetine (an antidepressant) and lamotrigine (an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer) in addition to kratom. For 173 (26.2%) exposure calls, no effects were reported, or poison center staff members were unable to follow up again regarding effects. Among exposed persons for whom information on signs and symptoms was available, reported signs and symptoms included tachycardia (n = 165, 25.0%), agitation or irritability (157, 23.8%), drowsiness (128, 19.4%), nausea (97, 14.7%), and hypertension (77, 11.7%). 

AS you can see from this information most of the exposures resulted in mild adverse effects with more severe effects and one death due to multiple substance ingestion. 
(see https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27466822) 

In reviews conducted in 2012 and again this year, Walter Prozialeck, PhD, chairman of the Department of Pharmacology at the Chicago College of Osteopathic Medicine, Midwestern University, in Illinois, and colleagues found that kratom likely has some legitimate and important uses.e cites several studies that offer proof that the mitragynines  the active substances in kratom  have different molecular actions than opioids.
(see http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/872535)

Therefore, I am asking that the DEA defer regulation of kratom to the FDA 


Thank you, 
Sam Russo ND, LAc, RMSK
Winooski, VT

I was only contacting her just to verify she was still alive, I had to keep her at a distance because she would even try to manipulate me to get money.

She making tea and reporting back that it didn't taste good at all, but it did help with her pain, and withdraw symptoms when she didn't have pills. Fast forward to 2016, I can say that she has all but weened herself off of opiate pills (prescription and black market) and uses kratom tea and OTC pain medicine a couple times a week as needed to help control her pain. What I didn't expect to happen is to see a junkie slowly transform back into a mother. She came back to me and my siblings after 20 years of being gone from opiates. It hurts as much as it's a relief because of where the DEA and FDA stand on this herbal tea moving forward. I'm scared that we may lose what took us 20 years to find! I began using Kratom as an alternative to opiate painkillers (hydrocodone, oxycodone, tramadol) as a means of managing pain associated with numerous sports injuries accumulated over the years (herniated disc with sciatica, torn TCCF, torn AC ligament from multiple shoulder dislocations - those are only the major ones). Surgery is a risk I'm not currently willing to undergo.  

Fearing the possibility of addiction after seeing numerous friends and one family member wind up in the hospital from opiate overdose (and two friends die from overdose), I would typically rotate through several opiate medications with 'off' periods between dosing cycles.  This was typically a month-on, month-off arrangement.  Synthetic opiates were at best effective for two weeks, after which time the pain would start to seep back in.  Terrified to up the dosage, I would keep taking the same dose and suffer through the less-effective treatment.  So, for 6 weeks out of every 8 I was not able to lift my right arm above my head, rotate my right wrist, bend or twist at the waist, or squat without severe pain.  During the four weeks I was on painkillers, I traded constant gnawing pain for constipation, difficulty sleeping, nausea, and mental confusion.  Plus, the overarching fear that I would wind up a pharma-junkie.

I was turned on to Kratom in January of 2016 by a well-meaning "herbalist" hippie-type (I live near Boulder CO).  Usually I don't place any faith in that sort of pseudoscience, so I was amazed to find that Kratom actually worked to treat my symptoms.  In an attempt to be cautious, I initially stuck with my opiate dosing schedule - 4 weeks on, 4 weeks off.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that there were very minor side effects - no itchiness, no difficulty sleeping, mild nausea, and crystal-clear mental clarity.  I was also surprised to find that the same dosage was just as effective at day 28 as it was at day 1.  Presently, I take approximately 3g of Kratom powder twice a day.  I usually skip at least one weekend day, and occasionally take a week off just to make sure I'm not building a tolerance.  I have experienced ZERO withdrawal symptoms during these times.

But Kratom might provide more than safe, effective, and only mildly addictive pain relief.  People claim that Kratom has antidepressant or antianxiety properties.  I'm not sure whether that's the case, but I can see how there might be sort of placebo effect.  For example, imagine after living with constant pain for years.  Now, imagine being able to sleep a full night through without waking up in pain.  Imagine being able to twist on the toilet seat to wipe properly without pain.  Imagine being able to wash your feet in the shower without pain.  Imagine being able to cook, clean, fold laundry - without pain.  Imagine being able to sit down at a computer and type a letter without pain.  I personally feel a lot better simply because I can do these things; my self-confidence has improved.  Others claim Kratom can be used to recover from opiate addiction.  While I wouldn't consider myself an opiate addict, I can see some validity to those claims as well.  And frankly, this country needs some better options - the costs in medical care and life due to the present opiate epidemic are staggering.  50000 people a year, and billions of dollars for medical care.  What we have now is not working.

Don't turn your back on those people by making them criminals for combating the pain that is their reward for fighting FOR us.  I have seen firsthand the horrors caused by opiate addiction - If there is an option to help those people don't make it illegal; don't condemn thousands of people and their families to a slow spiral into addiction.  Don't make ME turn to illegal sources to effectively address my pain.

When 50+ members of Congress and 100,000+ American citizens can agree that the DEA is acting out of line, maybe it's time to step back, reevaluate, and take a different approach.  Oh sure, I know it's technically legal to ban a substance without consulting anyone, but that doesn't make it right.

documents.commentText: (Note: I'm a tenured college professor promoted to the rank of full professor. I am not a medical doctor.) I have been using kratom with some regularity for approximately three years. For me, the effects can best be described as "mildly relaxing." It is not nearly as sedating as a glass of wine, and is about as relaxing as chamomile tea. For me, is no more addictive than coffee. There might some moderate psychological addiction but it's more connected to the familiarity of a pleasant routine than to physical changes in the brain chemistry of the user. I have often stopped taking kratom quite suddenly with no serious withdrawal effects other than brief intestinal distress. For me, the best thing about the plant is that it's great for irritable bowel syndrome. Without going into too much detail, it firms everything up. Unlike many substances considered to be recreational drugs, kratom does not really reward increasing the dose with stronger effects. Cranking up the dose simply makes it likely that a person will feel sick to the stomach and a bit woozy, just as drinking six cups of coffee might cause stomach problems and wooziness. For me, if kratom is made illegal, it is simply an inconvenience. I will miss the ritual, but life will go on. However, I am deeply concerned about the many thousands of Americans who have used kratom as a way of eliminating their dependence on opiates. I realize that the evidence is anecdotal, but there is plenty of this evidence, and the testimonials are overwhelming. So many people who have struggled with opiate addiction have been able to cut opiates out of their lives with the help of kratom. Without hyperbole, I believe that rescheduling kratom could have a terrible effect on many thousands of people. The DEA's announcement suggested that Kratom is responsible for countless calls to poison control, but a closer examination of the evidence reveals that very few incidents have been linked specifically to Katom. The DEA proposed adding Kratom to Schedule I without a serious review of the available scientific literature. If you search Google for "Mitragyna speciosa," you will find more than 1,000 search results documenting the potential medical value of kratom. Yet, the DEA has concluded unilaterally that the supplement has no meaningful medical benefits. I suspect that some at the DEA made the mistake of confusing Kratom with synthetic cathinones known as "bath salts." I think all reasonable people can agree that bath salts are terribly dangerous and should be banned. Kratom is not remotely close to bath salts. I also want to acknowledge that there is little "quality control" as far as importing the plant is concerned. It would be nice if there were some sort of regulation -- perhaps random sampling and leaf testing for all imports -- in an attempt to ensure that users are not subjected to heavy metal poisoning and/or contaminated samples. However, if the regulation is too restrictive -- if it chokes off the smaller suppliers -- I fear that it will be almost the same effect as a total ban. I also suspect that this type of regulation would be outside the scope of the DEA. Thanks for opening up to public comments. In closing, I just want to reiterate how valuable this plant seems to be for many recovering opiate addicts. This is not my situation, but I worry about the many who might be affected by this.

Dear Agency Representatives,

I use kratom for inoperable back pain and have been successfully using it to reduce need for synthetic opiates like hydrocodone. Kratom has proven to me personally to be a safe, reasonable alternative--finally! Banning this benevolent herb would, to me, represent a real setback.

I recommend that Krapton not be placed into Schedule I. Below I present the following arguments for your consideration:

1) With over 25 different alkaloids, we do not fully have the science to understand this plant. In such cases, traditional cultural use over multiple decades should be taken into consideration. In cultures where the plant grows, it has been safely used as a traditional medicine. Leaves are chewed to relieve musculoskeletal pain, increase energy, appetite, and sexual desire (see Warner ML, Kaufman NC, Grundmann O (2016). "The pharmacology and toxicology of kratom: from traditional herb to drug of abuse". Int. J. Legal Med. (Review). 130 (1): 127-38.)
2) While plant pharmacology is not fully understood, we know that some alkaloids in the plant act on opioid receptors and relieve pain. A key benefit that users are reporting is that Kraton can be an effective alternative to opioid based medicines which are highly addictive and have serious side effects. The key is that pain relief from Kraton is reported at relatively low doses (1-5g of raw leaves), which are below the threshold for dependence and negative long-term side effects (>15g of raw leaves). See Warner ML, Kaufman NC, Grundmann O (2016). "The pharmacology and toxicology of kratom: from traditional herb to drug of abuse". Int. J. Legal Med. (Review). 130 (1): 127-38
3) While there is some evidence for addiction potential, this is not yet well understood. The CDC reports of poisoning (~660) are a concern but need to be fully understood before take away the public's right to access a potentially beneficial plant. For example, did any deaths involve the traditional use of chewing leaves or where processed extracts involved? Were the deaths really driven by Kraton or driven by other circumstances (e.g. concurrent Opioid use, health issue, etc.) A review of the peer reviewed literature shows that serious toxicity is relatively rare and generally appears at high doses (beyond those need for medicinal use) or when Kratom is used with other substances. See Rech, MA; Donahey, E; Cappiello Dziedzic, JM; Oh, L; Greenhalgh, E (February 2015). "New drugs of abuse.". Pharmacotherapy. 35 (2): 189-97 

In conclusion, while the DEA concerns due to reported poisonings are understandable, based (a) on our current early scientific knowledge, (b) the large numbers of reported positive US user personal experiences, and (c) the long-term accepted medicinal properties of the plant in societies that have been using the plant for many decades, the move to put Krapton on Schedule I is unwarranted. Based on the evidence presented above, such a move would be detrimental to our society and an unnecessary loss of personal freedom and choice for citizens looking into new ways to manage their health issues with alternative natural substances. A few irresponsible recreational users that take excessive (and possibly processed/concentrated) dosages outside of the culturally proven safe medicinal use of 1-5g of raw plant material should not cause a responsible institution like the DEA to overreact and remove access of this medicinal plant to the thousands of users that claim relief from it.

Thank you,

Dr. Manuel Breva, PhD.

Although I do not partake in the supplement kratom myself, my husband (a disabled US Army veteran) has found great relief in its use with his anxiety, depression, and PTSD. He uses this leaf as a tisane - steeping the crushed leaves in water and drinking it, and does this in addition to taking his depression/anxiety medicine prescribed to him by the VA to give him a better quality of life. 

Since we discovered this plant almost a year ago, his quality of life has increased tenfold, and he has been much happier and healthier than when he was on his medication alone. He has less trouble going out into crowds (like grocery store, traffic, movies, amusement parks), which previously were extremely difficult tasks for him to manage. Please, do not schedule the supplement kratom as a schedule 1 drug.

My name is Spenser Sullivan and I'm from Las Vegas, Nevada. I agree that both Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine should be placed into a schedule; however, placing them into schedule 1 would be a mistake for a few reasons. First of all, placing Kratom into schedule 1 would mean that "The drug or other substance has no currently accepted

My name is Heather and I am a 39-year-old Computer Science student and former business analyst. I oppose any scheduling of kratom!
I started consuming kratom about 18 months ago when looking for natural herbs and vitamins that could help me to feel better while quitting drinking. The reason I was looking for these natural herbs is because I have a severe alcohol problem that was destructive to myself and those around me. I had tried everything I could think of to stop drinking. I went to many 12-step groups (including 90 meetings in 90 days), years of therapy with multiple psychologist, psychiatrists and addiction specialists. I even tried prescription drugs designed to help discourage drinking or reduce cravings, such as Antabuse and Naltrexone. These things helped slightly, but I was still not able to give up drinking, despite my deep desire to stop. My addiction defied all logic. I was even in trouble with the law. No matter what the consequences, I simply could not stop!
I have always known I was a good person, but I could not get away from the alcohol long enough to prove it. Alcohol had me hooked and I could not control my desire to drink. Because I am a determined person,  I started searching for unorthodox help since the conventional things I tried were not sufficient.
I found kratom, along with many other helpful herbs, on a forum where people were discussing supplements and botanicals. Kratom, along with vitamin D, B-Complex and other herbs like Ashwaghanda, has been an invaluable tool for my sobriety. It helped me to get sober by giving me energy and a feeling of wellbeing I had never had before. It helps me to feel like a normal person, and that is all I want.
I am not searching for a high. I live in a state where I can get alcohol or recreational marijuana if I wanted that. According to my definition of getting high, I do not get high from kratom, though I do feel better. It is hard to describe. It just makes me feel what I imagine is normal for many people. It helps me get on with the hard work of changing my life.
I have been sober since July 14, 2015. I have not been sober this long since I was 17. By improving my energy levels and reducing the terrible pain I feel from my mental health problems, kratom has helped give me my life back and I no longer feel the need for alcohol.
Since starting kratom, I have been a better student and have had the ability to keep a high GPA and even receive multiple academic scholarships. Kratom didnt do all of this for me. I still had to work very hard, but being able to stay sober and feel better made it possible to pursue my education and to fulfill my dream of working as a programmer. Because I have been able to stay sober, I am also a better mother, friend and community member. I have turned my life around in nearly every way!
Kratom is something that should remain available as a dietary supplement. I am not opposed to regulation. I think its good to have some standards in place, as long as those standards do not hamper people who need this herb for their continued wellbeing.
If kratom is taken away, I fear I may return to alcohol. Kratom does not replace alcohol for me, it just supports my sobriety. I only know that it works for me, and it has not caused me any addiction or unwanted effects. I have stopped taking kratom many times after long periods of daily consumption without having to worry about any serious symptoms other than a returning of the mental pain and craving for alcohol. Also, Kratom has many different varieties and it is important to me to be able to adjust the amount I take and the type I take based on how I am feeling each day. Kratom is an important part of a healthy life for many people in America. Please keep kratom available to all American adults who wish to use it. I believe this is important for the health of our country!

documents.commentText:
Dear Drug Enforcement Administration,

I appreciate your consideration in temporarily withdrawing your intent to schedule kratom as schedule I, and especially for soliciting public comments. In reading through many comments, I see those attesting to the value (though empirically under-analyzed) of kratom for treatment of chronic pain, especially considering the addicting, disruptive, and harmful alternative of opioid medication. I do not share this experience, however, though I believe that it alone is sufficient to suspend an intent to schedule kratom until more conclusive data arrives. 

My experience involves being a Ph.D. candidate at the University of California, where I also teach undergraduate courses. Due to the nature of being a doctoral student, extreme amounts of stress cause a number of students to either drop out of doctoral programs or to use opioid or antidepressant medication to manage anxiety. Doctoral programs are often labeled as programs of "psychological warfare," testing just how much a student is capable of enduring. 

Therefore, I have turned to kratom (moderately and intermittently) to manage extreme periods of stress, particularly during my previous Ph.D. examination, in addition to intense periods of research, writing, and publishing. In four years in the program, I have suffered no ill effects or side effects from kratom. In addition, when I go on vacation, for example, I do not bring my kratom with me. Several weeks go by without any kratom use, and without any physical or psychological addiction. In my experience, and in the experience of the vast majority of other kratom users, kratom is a relatively harmless drug with mild but valuable effects. Kratom does not impair my judgment, state of consciousness, focus, or motor skills. In fact, it is precisely kratom which, during these extreme periods of stress, calms my mind and facilitates momentary rest. 

You might wonder why rely on kratom for such effects. Why not learn to do without? Surely, it is doable. Let me provide an analogy. During extreme periods of work, I rely on coffee to sustain my focus, intensity, and dedication to my projects. I am not addicted to coffee, nor is it impossible to do work without it, but coffee provides an assistance that is invaluable, and since moderate use comes with no ill effects, it seems rational and beneficial to accept what it can offer to me in certain situations. 

The same goes with kratom -- expect that instead of utilizing kratom to work, as I do coffee, I utilize it to shift my concentration from work to rest. As you know, kratom and coffee are related species, and offer similar effects depending on dosage. In this sense, I believe moderation is the key, as both species may have negative effects to health with immoderate use. 

Kratom, however, has not been demonstrated among its five million users in the USA to have either the psychological or physical effects (in terms of health and state of mind) as schedule I drugs like heroin or LSD. Furthermore, as you are aware, research on kratom has significant potential to alter the course of opioid addiction, which kills many thousands more than the few who have died from kratom in relation to use of other drugs. 

For this reason and many others, I would ask that you sustain kratom's availability, thereby sustaining active research in the field, as well as sustaining an alternative to opioid addiction for the public. I ask that you trust the general public (despite inevitable cases of misuse and abuse, though small in comparison with most any other drug) to regulate their use of the drug, and to consume moderately. However, I understand that regulation in the future from the FDA would be a wise action. I simply ask for time. Rather than temporarily scheduling kratom, I ask that you temporarily sustain its availability so that further research can be done. I am aware that the research on kratom is inconclusive and often anecdotal, as is my testimony; on the other hand, this limited research does not discount the apparent promise of kratom, and the multitudes of anecdotal evidence from users is quite promising in and of itself (not including specialists in medicine).

Consequently, if kratom even has a remote possibility to facilitate many of the problems that many in medicine (and the general public) state that it can, I believe it is truly worthwhile to sustain kratom's availability, even if temporarily.

Thank you. I appreciate your time and consideration, and for creating this opportunity for what has hopefully been a professional public discourse on this important and consequential matter. I anxiously await your response and trust in your decision for the good of the general public and for our medical institutions.

The DEA plans on making Kratom a Schedule I substance. The following findings are required for drugs to be placed in this schedule:

-The drug or other substance has a high potential for abuse.
-The drug or other substance has no currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States.
-There is a lack of accepted safety for use of the drug or other substance under medical supervision.

Kratom does not fit either of these 3 categories. The psychoactive effect of Kratom is subtle and many people would not even consider it a "high". Its users report many benefits from using Kratom, such as:
-Reduced anxiety
-Increased energy
-Pain management
-Cough Suppression
-Addiction recovery
-Lower blood pressure
-Insulin regulation.

The only real side effect of Kratom is withdrawal symptoms that can be very easily avoided by not taking very often. These side effects only occur if taken every or almost every day for a considerable amount of time. Other minor side effects are itchiness, nausea and slight constipation. These are minimal compared to the benefits it produces.
It is also very useful to significantly reduce the withdrawal symptoms from stopping opiates.

documents.commentText:
I am an Emergency Physician at a high volume institution in California. I am strongly opposed to the proposed scheduling of Kratom.
 
I spend my days seeing patients that are suffering from substance related illness. The most common being tobacco, alcohol and opiate related illness.
 
Two of the aforementioned substances are completely legal for consumption by adults, however, they pose a serious health threat to our community. The CDC says over 480,000 Americans die each year from tobacco-induced illness (1 in every 5 US deaths). Another 41,000 non-smokers die from diseases caused by secondhand smoke. Upwards of 14,000 people in 2014 died from prescription narcotics. The statistics for alcohol are equally alarming.
 
Research has overwhelmingly shown that alcohol and tobacco have zero health benefit. Consumption of either of these two substances is nothing but detrimental to health.
 
Additionally, alcohol, tobacco and narcotics are extremely addictive. So addictive, in fact, that I see patients continue to use these substances even when they are suffering from severe substance-related illness.
 
What I dont see during my shifts in the Emergency Department are patients with Kratom-related illness. There is not a single instance in which I have seen a patient present to the Emergency department due to Kratom-related illness. Upon reviewing the most commonly cited instances of Kratom-related death, I have found that the overwhelming majority of them clearly involved multi drug abuse.
 
My personal experience with Kratom has been that the only adverse event that results from taking too much is vomiting.  While I dont take Kratom on a daily basis, I have taken it occasionally (maybe two to three times per month) for increased energy. On the other hand, I know plenty of people who suffer from serious illness and use the herbal supplement on a daily basis to successfully manage their illness.  I have also read many hundreds of testimonials of people who have benefited from this herbal supplement.
 
I would never prescribe Kratom to a patient.  Similarly, I would never prescribe other herbal supplements such as turmeric, black cohosh or Echinacea, all of which have health benefits.  My practice is limited to that which I have studied and that which has been accepted by the medical community. It is up to my patients whether or not they want to take advantage of herbal remedies that have been used for thousands of year prior to the advent of the pharmaceutical industry. I use many herbal supplements myself.
 
As an Emergency Physician, I am acutely aware that Kratom does not pose a serious health threat to our community. If it did, it would be my job to be aware of it and know how to treat it. 
 
I am shocked that there is a push to criminalize a benign herbal supplement that has been shown to benefit so many.  The only regulation that may be beneficial is to require vendors to document purity of product in order to avoid the sale of adulterated product.
 
If the goal of the DEA is to ban substances that pose significant health threats to our community, tobacco, alcohol and prescription narcotics should be first on the list.

Sincerely,

Addie J Davis, MD

I have personally been trauma and health issues in the form of auto and motorcycle crashes,  sports related injuries,  chemotherapy treatment, and more. As a result,  I suffer from chronic pain.  I was prescribed numerous pain medications over the last 25 years,  and my life suffered immensely. 

The pain medication turned me into a zombie,  and I felt terrible and had overwhelming depression and side effects . I didn't want to live my life this way. 

5 years ago I read about an herbal supplement called kratom that came from the ground leaves of a tree from Southeast Asia. There were numerous people saying that it helped them with chronic pain,  and I found the same result. I was amazed at how well the leaves from this tree,  which is related to coffee,  reduced my pain and stiffness which also improved my mood. I was able to completely stop taking prescription pain medication and NSAIDs,  and I felt better than I had in 18 years. 

When using consuming kratom leaf powder,  I was able to resume working full time,  training at the gym,  and doing all of the outdoor things that I love. My marriage to a wonderful woman,  my awesome job,  and my life were and still are better than ever. I have even started more education and more volunteer work with lower income people and families

Kratom leaf powder is a very helpful herbal supplement,  and in the last 5 years I have seen it benefit hundreds of people. I have witnessed many people eliminate their debilitating opiate dependency, both legal and illegal, by taking it, and likely save lives because of that. It is not used to "get high" by anyone In have ever known or worked with - it is simply used to feel better or feel normal again. 

Please don't make kratom a schedule 1 drug like heroin.  It is inexpensive,  safe,  and has done wonders for me and many others. I am terrified that my access to this will be eliminated and I will be forced to go back on addictive opiates and become a zombie again,  or else I will become a felon and face long prison terms for simply trying to feel better. 

Sincerely. 

Robert Ector

documents.commentText: Hello.  I am a chef, and farmer who has found the issue of Kratom legislation important enough to submit a comment.  I am fairly new to this plant, and only learned of it after the proposed emergency scheduling, a couple months ago. I am somewhat knowledgeable about botanical medicines, and plants in general.  When Kratom is fresh and pure, it produces mild analgesia and calmness.  A lucid energetic boost is also common of some strains.  Sleep is somewhat deeper after a Kratom dose, and the following morning it is common to feel more refreshed than usual.  The side effects of Kratom may involve stomach upset,  and some mild anxiety and soreness the following day.  Although all of these negative effects combined are still quite negligible, especially in comparison to any pharmaceutical drug that treats pain or anxiety, but still deserve to be noted.  I was in a car accident several years ago, and deal on a regular basis with a fair amount of pain. Over the counter, NSAID medication like Advil provides minor relief.  I have never, and will never use illegal opioids, because I care about my health, and have no desire to break the law.      I don't drink or smoke.  I was prescribed oxycodone after being released from the hospital from orthopedic surgery following my accident.  Although I was in a great deal of pain, the side effects of this drug were too great, and I refrained from using it all but about 3 times during the hardest part of my recovery period.  Depression, intense headaches, mood swings, muscle spasms, and a long grueling recovery are just a few of the side effects related to the use of oxycodone.  Although much time has passed, my work is full of physical labor and long hours on my feet which can often exacerbate my condition, resulting in pain and reduced mobility.  I believe discovering Kratom was a gift in the treatment of pain.  I do not take Kratom very often, a couple of times a month when my pain is at its worst, never more frequently than once a week.  I haven't found it to be addictive or physically/mentally damaging, when taken this way and in low doses.  It is empowering to know I have an herbal tool for the treatment of moderate to severe pain and anxiety.  Keeping such a plant legal could empower others to make healthier choices, and help deal with the epidemic of prescription and illegal drug use.  It is also clear that this plant isn't entirely harmless, few medicines are.  More scientific studies should be done to create a clear and unbiased picture.  Safeguards should be set in place to ensure purity of therapeutic Kratom from legitimate authorized retailers.  Scheduling Kratom could have the negative effect of turning some users to harder drugs.  Organized crime could take control of the supplies of this plant, fueling the illicit cartels that your organization opposes.  All for a plant that shares more in common with coffee than with opium.  In my unprofessional opinion, it is clear that Kratom has many therapeutic uses, and that the threat posed by Kratom to the public's health is considerably less than tobacco, alcohol, and prescription opioids and anxiolytics.

documents.commentText:
The Federal Government should not be deciding the fate of Kratom.

Kratom does have some opiate and stimulant like properties. But many plants, supplements, beverages, and foods available to the public have psychoactive properties. Many of these things, such as caffeine and tobacco, are highly addictive.

Scheduling a substance like Kratom in the top tier of the controlled substance list will automatically make any current user a criminal. Further, it will make any future user a criminal. This is huge overreach for a drug that is not particularly abused, does not have a high likelihood of abuse, and when it is abused, it's abuse is comparable to other slightly psychoactive substances, and abuse of those substances are completely legal and often socially acceptable.

A top tier scheduling of Kratom will also create huge barriers to research on the substance. The substance is currently considered not to have any medicinal qualities by the DEA, but it also has not been researched much in the United States. Schedule 1 substances are so heavily controlled, domestic research is all but entirely stalled. A good example is with marijuana research, in which most research into the medicinal benefits of marijuana are done outside the United States (http://www.newsweek.com/2015/12/25/outsourcing-american-marijuana-research-406184.html)

Top tier scheduling also makes a substance almost impossible to reschedule. Again, using marijuana as an example, countries around the world, and many states within the US, have decided that marijuana does have medicinal properties. Yet the DEA refuses to reschedule the drug. If Marijuana was a schedule 2 or schedule 3 drug today, ask yourself, would the DEA be trying to make it a schedule 1?


I do not believe that the DEA's scheduling system of drugs accurately reflects a substance's amount of harm in society, but I do understand that it is Congress that wrote the CSA and the DEA's job to enforce that law. I do not think Kratom should be scheduled, and should remain unregulated just as caffeine and other minor psychoactive are unregulated. For use in food products, regulation of Kratom should follow under the powers of the FDA, not the DEA.

If the DEA decides it should be regulating minor psychoactive substances such as caffeine and Kratom, I believe it should do so without criminalizing the thousands of people that currently use the substance. I also believe that it should not put limits on research and medicinal possibilities by prematurely scheduling it as a schedule 1 substance.

Instead, the DEA should make all attempts to understand its medicinal possibilities, determine the safety of its use, and determine its actual likelihood of abuse/dependency as compared to other substances that are considered highly dependent-forming or abused.

I also believe that Donald Trump should not be president, but this has nothing to do with Kratom. Happy October!

documents.commentText: Dear DEA Officials:  My name is Tanya Yearout and I reside in the state of Missouri. I'm 59 years old.  I'm a professional transcriptionist and I'm married with four beautiful grandchildren.  Kratom saved my life!! Please consider not classifying it as a scheduled 1 drug. I suffer from severe fibromyalgia with osteoarthritis, not to mention Chronic fatigue.  I'm a daily chronic pain sufferer.  Approximately one year ago I read about Kratom through Face Book and decided to try it.  THIS HERB HAS SAVED MY LIFE.  I was on sooo many medications for this disorder Gabapentin, Savella, Hydrocodone, Tramadol, and Lyrica was too expensive.  I had literally reached the end of my rope with this pain/fatigue.  I had no life! Even the air from the ceiling fan hurt my skin.   The sad part nothing was helping very well.  Would wake up at night in such pain I would cry and walk the floor.  I would even have to take a nap after taking a shower I was sooo tired daily.  I slept off and on spending nearly all my time in bed due to pain/fatigue.  I was so depressed I literally was contemplating taking my own life (if you can call what I just described as a life).  I tried Kratom and ohhhh my God what a difference it has made in my life.  It takes my pain level down more than any Rx and I now have energy to face the day...and SPEND time with my grandchildren.  I have thrown all my Rxs away (this was one year ago this December).  I'm sure I would most likely be dead right now if I had not discovered Kratom.  This plant has helped thousands and thousands of people with little side effects for myself.  It is a remarkable herb and should not be taken off the market or Scheduled.  I might agree if there was an age restriction like on alcohol (which kills people every single day and cigarettes).  Please thank you for this consideration.
